channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Trump Secures New Trade Deal Frameworks in Europe and Latin America
item.description: The White House hopes to lower prices on key food items as well as pharmaceuticals.

item.title: Trump Scores New Trade Deals
item.description: The White House hopes to lower prices on key food items as well as pharmaceuticals.

item.title: The Trump Trade Tracker
item.description: Switzerland cuts a deal—plus the latest global picture on Trump’s tariff regime.

item.title: Has Chinese Power Peaked in Asia?
item.description: Beijing finds itself in a precarious geopolitical position.

item.title: What in the World?
item.description: Test yourself on the week of Nov. 8: The U.N. climate conference begins, the U.S. government shutdown ends, and Iraq votes.

item.title: Who the Hell Is James Garfield?
item.description: Netflix’s “Death by Lightning” is a reminder that heroic individuals can emerge in trying hours.

item.title: A Pair of Haunting New Scandinavian Novels
item.description: Plus, more international fiction releases.

item.title: How Chile Was Persuaded to Vote ‘No’ to Dictatorship
item.description: Revisiting Pablo Larraín’s feature film about the advertising campaign that sent Pinochet packing.

item.title: Cover Story newsletter: How markets could topple the economy
item.description: An exclusive look at how we designed our cover

item.title: A Power-Hungry Southeast Asia Wants China’s Energy
item.description: Renewables are in hot demand in a growing region.

item.title: Trump’s War on the BBC Is Working
item.description: The U.S. government has pushed the legendary broadcaster into a nervous breakdown.

item.title: Today’s Electricity Revolution Is Missing a Key Ingredient
item.description: While renewables and electrification are quickly transforming energy systems around the world, fragmentation between nodes on the network creates unnecessary inefficiencies, raises costs, stifles innovation, and makes it harder to realize the benefits of digitalization. That is why interoperability has become an urgent priority.

item.title: China’s Upgraded Lawfare in the South China Sea
item.description: China is stepping up its legal narratives targeting the Philippines.

item.title: Cracking Southeast Asia’s Scam Economy
item.description: Washington and London’s recent unprecedented actions showed what global coordination can achieve – and what remains to be done.

item.title: Trump’s Dangerous Liaison With Pakistan
item.description: With a combination of flattery, symbolic gestures, and promises of personal enrichment, Pakistan seems to have cracked the code for dealing with US President Donald Trump. Meanwhile, the United States has turned its back on India – and on a strategic partnership that is crucial for countering China.

item.title: Revisiting Pakistan’s Climate Journey: From Global Spotlight to Ground Realities
item.description: The absence of the prime minister and other senior federal figures at COP30 suggests evolving priorities and moderated expectations.

item.title: A Glimpse of the Future of China-US Relations
item.description: If the current trajectory holds, the rivalry will harden into a permanent conflict in the next few years. But it's not too late to change course.

item.title: Purges and Power: Is China Quietly Rebalancing Its Command Structure?
item.description: Is collective decision making slowly re-emerging in the CCP?

item.title: How Asia Is Navigating America’s Fading Financial Control
item.description: Across Asia, governments are learning to live with U.S. financial dominance – without depending on it.

item.title: Nigeria’s Lessons for Emerging Economies
item.description: Nigeria’s recent removal from the Financial Action Task Force’s Grey List is the result of close coordination among policymakers, regulators, and law enforcement. It shows that when emerging markets muster the political will to pursue comprehensive reforms, the international financial system takes notice.

item.title: Kazakhstan’s ‘Eternal’ and Pragmatic Relations on Display in Russia Visit
item.description: Less than a week after visiting Donald Trump in the White House, Kazakh President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev traveled to Russia to further the countries’ proclaimed “eternal alliance.”

item.title: Amid Taiwan’s Diplomatic Blitz in Europe, China Threatens to Weaponize Interpol
item.description: Three prominent DPP politicians were in Europe this month.

item.title: As Asia Advances LGBTQ+ Rights, Japan’s Parliament Stalls
item.description: The political space for action exists. What’s missing is leadership willing to act on what courts have already decided.

item.title: When It Comes to Oil and Gas, Japan Can Still Say ‘No’
item.description: Japan is most likely to diverge from U.S. foreign policy positions when its energy security is at stake.

item.title: President Lee Jae-myung’s Latest Headache
item.description: Prosecutors and the opposition party are elevating their attacks on Lee over a recent court ruling.

item.title: Do women need testosterone supplements?
item.description: It can be helpful in some cases, but it’s no fountain of youth

item.title: Malabar Exercises Underway, Despite Turbulence in the Quad
item.description: While the Quad leaders are unlikely to meet this year, Malabar 2025 is going ahead.

item.title: Local Meets Global at COP30 in Belém
item.description: Latin American climate solutions are on display at the annual summit.

item.title: Rare Earths Roil China-EU Relations
item.description: Despite a recent de-escalation, China-EU relations are far from normal.

item.title: American Automakers Need Chinese Batteries
item.description: High political walls are hurting an industry vital to the character of the country.

item.title: Free Trade Can’t Bring Peace
item.description: For decades, the liberal belief that open trade fosters peace has shaped US foreign policy. It worked while US security guarantees held the system together, but as those commitments weaken and new powers assert themselves, the multilateral trading order is rapidly coming undone.

item.title: The Forever Protectorate
item.description: Thirty years after Dayton, Bosnia is still overseen by a foreigner who has become a source of political instability.

item.title: Australia’s Shock Defense Wake-up Call
item.description: ‘Down under’ isn’t that far away from trouble

item.title: The world is getting on with tackling climate change. Australia can’t afford to be left behind
item.description: While ambition at COP30 is still a long way from what’s needed, most countries are maintaining their commitments to act.

item.title: Landmines and Civilian Shootings Leave Thai-Cambodian Peace Deal in Tatters
item.description: Cambodia’s Prince Group denies claims of involvement in online scamming operations, alleges U.S. conspiracy.

item.title: Thailand’s King Vajiralongkorn Arrives in Beijing For Historic Visit
item.description: The five-day visit is the first by a sitting Thai monarch since the establishment of diplomatic relations between Bangkok and Beijing in 1975.

item.title: The End of China’s Old Guard
item.description: Why party elders can’t save the country from Xi.

item.title: America’s Quasi Alliances
item.description: How Washington should manage its most complicated relationships.

item.title: After the Gen Z Quake, Nepali Congress Fights for its Future
item.description: Even though Nepal’s Grand Old Party has strong second-generation leaders ready to take leadership and most of the party wants the same, the old guard is able to cling on.
